entries.text:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com
entries.title: We're Hiring Perl Software Developers - Grant Street Group

entries.text: Do you take pride in your craft and want to have fun() at the same time? Are you a geek? Join the team of iwantmyname from anywhere.
entries.title: Back-End Blacksmith

entries.text: Autoderef was added to perl in version 5.14 and now it seems to be on the way out. chromatic asked your opinion if you will miss it. I think very few people have really used it. Have you?
entries.title: Would You Miss Autoderef in 5.20?

entries.author: jt_smith
entries.text: JT Smith suggests that making something work today is more important than 'doing it right'. Not everyone agrees with him.
entries.title: Modular, Decoupled, Best Practiced, Well Designed, Bullshit

entries.author: steven_haryanto
entries.text: While CPAN has lots of modules solving many problems (multiple times), there are many problems that are not, or not well solved. Steven Haryanto started to put together a list of tools (libraries) available in other languages but not in Perl. In case you are looking for an problem to work on.
entries.title: Things we don't have #1

entries.author: toby_inkster
entries.text: Toby Inkster continues his quest to unify the way we can use Moose, Moo and Mouse. One of his suggestion is to write for Moo. Code written using Moo works well with Moose as well, and the syntactic sugar alll three provide is quite similar. So if you use that, your code will likely work with all 3.
entries.title: Acme-oop-ism Part Three: techniques

entries.text: This is the regular write-up of Toby Inkster on the world of Moose and friends. This episode includes an interview with Upasana Shukla who implemented the Moose exception objects as part of her OPW internship.
entries.title: Planet Moose - October 2013

entries.author: philippe_bruhat
entries.text: Do you have a Gti wrapper? Does it work? Philippe Bruhat (BooK) has created a GtiHub repository with lots of weird commits to test against.
entries.title: Test repository for Git wrappers

entries.author: tony_cook
entries.text: Tony Cook has requested an extension of $13,000 for his Maintaining Perl 5 grant.
entries.title: Grant Extension Request - Maintaining Perl 5

entries.text: Torsten Raudssus reports about the one week he worked on the grant since he started it in July.
entries.title: YACT - Yet Another Conference Tool - Grant Report #1

entries.text: Apparently there is a serious unicode bug in DBD::ODBC which affects inserts into char/varchar columns.
entries.title: DBD-ODBC 1.45 released to the CPAN + important warning

entries.text: This is the presentation of Bill Humphries at YAPC::NA about web frameworks for the client such as Backbone, Knockout, and Angular and how they work together with a Perl-based back-end.
entries.title: Perl Meets Modern Web UI

entries.text: Doran Barton gave this introductory talk at the monthly meeting of the Salt Lake Perl Mongers.
entries.title: Introduction to DBIx::Class

entries.author: john_napiorkowski
entries.text: This is expected to turn into the stable Catalyst 5.90050 release. Go test it.
entries.title: Perl Catalyst 'Hamburg' Development Release 5 on CPAN, Final Call For Comments!

entries.author: dominique_dumont
entries.text: Apparently LWP::UserAgent (and thus most Perl web clients that rely on it) cannot handle https requests via proxy. This bug was reported 10 years ago. Patches were submitted but the problem has not been fixed. Now Dominique Dumont explains the background of https and show how he proposed to fix the problem.
entries.title: About LWP::UserAgent, https and proxy setup

entries.author: joel_berger
entries.text: Joel Berger continued his article from last week.
entries.title: Writing Non-Blocking Applications with Mojolicious: Part 2

entries.author: thomas_klausner
entries.text: Thomas Klausner (domm) reports from Salzburg and shows us a T-shirt that can run.
entries.title: Austrian Perl Workshop 2013

entries.text: November 15-16, 2013, Curitiba, PR, Brazil
entries.title: YAPC::Brazil 2013

entries.text: November 23, 2013, Copenhagen, Denmark
entries.title: Nordic Perl Workshop 2013

entries.text: Saturday 30th November 2013 at Westminster University
entries.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW 2013)

entries.text: March 26-28, 2014, Hannover, Germany
entries.title: German Perl Workshop (GPW 2014)

chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
chapters.title: Events

header: Last week I had this little experience with various interesting Unicode characters in the Perl Weekly. On the web site it worked out well, but in the e-mail there were a few glitches. Most likely due to Mailman that I still use to handle the newsletter. (And it is a rather old version of Mailman, so I can't really blame it.) The subject line was missing the [Perlweekly] tag that Mailman should have included (and I hope it does this time again) and several people mentioned that they have not seen the heart in the subject line. I think the body of the message went through just fine.
subject: No Unicode in the subject line
